title: labour jeremy corbyn brexit
story: A nationwide campaign will be launched next week urging activists to sign a motion to be put to the vote at the Labour Party’s annual conference in Liverpool next month.A vote in favour at conference would compel the Labour leadership to accept a so-called “People’s Vote”. Sources told The Sun the motion may also demand Labour then campaign “to remain in the EU”.Some 130 constituency Labour parties (CLPs) are already though to be supporting the move.Critically the push is backed by union leaders – including TSSA chief Manuel Cortes. Sources claim Momentum co-founder Jon Lansmann is also supporting the idea.A source told The Sun: “An overwhelming number of Labour members and voters are fed up with Brexit. We believe a substantial number want the party to face up to Brexit extremists.”Jeremy Corbyn has repeatedly refused to rule out a second Referendum – with aides merely saying it is not current Labour policy.But Shadow Brexit Secretary Sir Keir Starmer last month said Labour could back a ‘People’s Vote’ if MPs reject Theresa May’s final deal with Brussels.At the time, he said: “In those circumstances it seems to me the sensible thing is to keep all our options on the table.”Union powerbroker Len McCluskey – the head of Labour donor Unite – last month said he was “open to the possibility” of a second vote.Labour opens the floor to motions by party members and activists on the Sunday of its annual conference. A panel of party bigwigs select a shortlist of motions that make it to the vote.Jeremy Corbyn suffered a major blow to his authority three years ago when unions and the membership rejected a bid for a vote on the renewal of the Trident nuclear deterrent at party conference.THE Pound slipped to its lowest level against the US dollar in nearly a year as traders worried about the growing possibility of a No-Deal.Sterling was down more than 0.4 per cent versus the dollar at 1.287 — its weakest point since last August.The UK currency also plunged 0.5 per cent against the euro, reaching its lowest since October.But the Pound’s tumble lifted the FTSE 100, as multinational companies listed on the index tend to benefit when foreign currencies are stronger than Sterling.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rod liddle building green spaces opinion
story: If it goes ahead with this, it will be the greatest act of vandalism against the British countryside in 200 years.It will also cost the Conservative Party hundreds of thousands of votes — perhaps millions.Because the people who live next to our beautiful open spaces tend to vote Tory.And they like looking at trees and fields rather than a Barratt estate.This is a crowded country and becoming ever more so. We’re losing more and more of our natural wildlife. Our open spaces diminish daily.And now the Government is being forced into building countless millions of homes. Why?We’re told we have a housing crisis. You might find this puzzling when you consider the birth rate in Britain has been dropping, not rising.The answer, of course, is immigration. We’ve been letting in half a million people every year for almost 15 years.The politicians try to tell you it’s nothing to do with our housing crisis — but they are lying. Lying to themselves and to you.One top academic expert, Oxford demographer David Coleman, reckons immigration is 85 per cent responsible for the rise in the UK’s population between 2000 and 2015.And the other figures you might find a bit chilling.Did you know, for example, that a whopping 28 per cent of all births in the UK are to foreign-born women? And the figure in London is a staggering 60 per cent.If you find an indigenous British person in London, say hello to him for me and wish him the best. He’s the last of a dying breed. White Brits are a minority in our capital.It’s not just that. The birth rate for British people is 1.75. The birth rate for immigrants is 2.06. That’s a very big difference.So not only do we let in half a million per year, but they have more kids and so doubly contribute to population growth and the need for new houses.Oh, and the need for lots of other very expensive stuff, such as schools, hospitals, welfare benefits and so on.We MUST call a halt to immigration. The overwhelming majority of the population thinks we need much tougher controls.And there are many people who think that immigration has not made the country any better, but actually made it worse.Cut the numbers coming in to 10,000 per year and our housing crisis would begin to lessen, given that 300,000 or so people emigrate every year.A net decrease in the population would massively reduce the need for new housing.Because unless we do that, the bulldozers will be moving in. The fields, hedges and woodland will be ripped up. The roads will be laid and the peace and quiet shattered.And this will not be a green and pleasant land for much longer.Katie Price has just managed to avoid being declared bankrupt.She’s been given three months to pay off a whole load of creditors, plus a whopping tax bill.Everyone seems shocked that she has apparently blown £45million.But that body needs a lot of upkeep. She spends thousands every month getting her nails done so they look really chavvy.And then there’s the periodic scaffolding required to keep those vast mammaries aloft – plus a bit of pointing and retiling.The surprise to me was how in the name of hell she managed to amass £45million, not how she managed to spend it.For doing WHAT exactly?A woman on a flight from Valencia to London apparently “bonded” with a “hot guy”.Now Jo Lia has launched a Facebook campaign to trace the poor bugger.She says he was called “Joe” and looked a bit like Jordan Henderson. Hmmm. But can he pass the ball sideways just as well? I bet she didn’t find that out. Anyway, above is a photo of Ms Lia.So Joe, mate – keep your head down and stay off social media for a while. If I had that loon sitting next to me on a plane I’d spend the entire flight in the khazi.Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn appeared on the Iranian-run Press TV to cast doubt on Israel’s right to exist.He used to get paid handsomely for his appearances on a network run by a hostile government which enslaves its own people.Meanwhile, more Labour anti-Semites have been crawling out of the woodwork.Here’s a suggestion. Clearly Labour has no intention of kicking out its Jew-haters.So I would suggest everyone in the party who ISN’T anti-Semitic get the hell out right now.And leave the party to the racist, hard-left rabble who are currently running it.The broadcaster Sandi Toksvig says that people mistake her for Tom Cruise.It’s easy to see why, isn’t it? Spitting image.Oddly enough, people often mistake me for the model Chloe Ayling.I even had the police round when she went missing because someone reckoned they’d seen her in Thornaby. But it was just me, nipping out for some fags.Our former Foreign Secretary is in trouble for having said that Muslim women wearing the full burka look like postboxes, or bank robbers.But that’s pretty much what most think, isn’t it?Boris was against banning the burka. But increasingly I think we should follow most of our European friends and outlaw the ridiculous garment in public places.Almost half of British 18 to 24 year olds don’t know when World War One took place, according to a survey.And hardly any of them could name the prime minister – David Lloyd George – who led us to victory.But it’s not really their fault, is it? Truth is, they’re not taught stuff like this any more.The history curriculum has been pretty much stripped of things which shows Britain in a good light, or British people being the victims of aggression.Instead, they learn very dubious arguments about slavery and colonialism.It’s a dangerous thing. When you lose a sense of pride in your nation, you also start to lose respect for its authority and its laws.And you raise a generation of perpetually whining airheads who understand nothing of the sacrifices made by Britons in the past.YOU see? They take their dieting really seriously up here in the North East. Pizza, chicken and chips. My missus took this pic, above, in a Teesside café.She once spent two weeks trying to find a salad in Austria, with no luck.The BBC is about to spend more than two million quid on a propaganda campaign to make you pay its licence fee.This is as opposed to the rest of its budget, which is spent on a propaganda campaign to convince you that all immigration is good, Israel is evil and Brexit a catastrophe.Fewer and fewer people watch the BBC.The licence fee has become an absurdity – an unjust tax which growing numbers of people simply refuse to pay.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: citizen juries introduced across the uk
story: Ministers will announce hopes for a revolution in local democracy in the first Civil Society strategy for 15 years.Under the plans, Citizens Juries will be set up in six towns and cities – giving residents a huge say on issues such as planning and spending.A ‘Citizens Assembly’ was credited with paving the way for Ireland’s historic decision earlier this year to radically change the country’s abortion laws.Similar Juries in Australia have seen panels of ordinary voters from all walks of life take decisions on the Sydney nightlife to nuclear storage.Sources claim the move follows attempts by Theresa May’s Government to address loneliness and exclusion earlier this year.Other initiatives could see the “mass participation” in community decisions by app or an online poll.A Government briefing said: “People should be able to take positive action on issues they care about throughout their lives.“The 21st century needs people power more than ever.”The Civil Society strategy will also see £90million released from so-called dormant bank accounts to get vulnerable youngsters into work.Some £20million will also be “unlocked” from charitable trusts to support community organisations.Tracey Crouch, Minister for Sport and Civil Society, said: “Civil society is the bedrock of our communities.It is made up of the volunteers, youth workers, charities and innovative businesses that work to improve lives and make better areas for all.“Our strategy builds on this spirit of common good to help create a country that works for everyone.”Labour’s Steve Reed panned the plan as an “underwhelming rehash of previously announced funding and empty gestures”.It is residents who know which roads need fixing, which bins need collecting, and which social care services are struggling.And for all the know-how of local councillors, too many are in safe seats and not solely motivated by serving their voters.Between plans for “citizen juries” and freeing up cash for community organisations, this should be a much-needed boost for local democracy — with the cash to back positive initiatives.The ironic thing is that it all sounds very familiar.It used to be called the Big Society.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: blokes boxer shorts dads higher chance
story: They produce more sperm than those who wear Y-fronts, briefs, or jockeys – and of a better quality.Experts say testicles function best at cooler temperatures and get too hot in most underwear.They suggest fellas make the “relatively easy” switch to boxers if they are trying for a baby.Medics from Harvard TH Chan School of Public Health, in the US, analysed samples from 656 blokes.They were aged between 18 and 56 and had an average BMI of 26 – mildly overweight.Just over half – 53 per cent – typically wore boxer shorts.They had 25 per cent higher sperm concentrations than those wearing other underwear.And they had a 17 per cent higher total sperm counts and 33 per cent more strong swimmers.Their sperm were also more likely to be correctly shaped.The most notable difference was between men who wore boxers and those who wore briefs.Study leader Dr Lidia Mingeuz-Alarcon said: “These results point to a relatively easy change that men can make when they and their partners are seeking to become pregnant.”The study, published in the journal Human Reproduction, is the largest ever into the effects of underwear on sperm.Commenting on the findings, Prof Richard Sharpe, from the University of Edinburgh, said: “Successful sperm production requires a temperature 3 to 4C below core body temperature.“This is achieved via a specialised blood cooling system and placement of the testes outside of the body in the scrotum.“It is well established that anything that interferes with maintenance of testes cooling is likely to impair sperm production and quality.“But the extent to which type of underwear worn might cause such interference has been a subject of debate for many years.“Wearing looser underwear and avoiding other sources of scrotal heating, such as hot baths and saunas, are easy adjustments for a man to take that might have a positive effect on his sperm.“This may increase the chances of achieving a pregnancy – although pregnancy success was not measured in this study.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: nasa astronaut encounter alien like object revealed
story: Leland Melvin, 54, worked as an engineer on board Atlantis when he came across the object while orbiting Earth.In a chat on Twitter with fans about his experiences in space he was asked if he had ever seen any aliens or UFOs.Melvin revealed that he had seen “something, organic, alien-like” in the payload bay of the shuttle when he was working with colleague Randy Bresnik.He added that he had notified NASA about the incident but it was put down to just ice breaking away from the vessel.The astronaut said the object he saw was “translucent, curved, organic looking” – ending his tweet with an alien emoji.He wrote: “I have not seen [a UFO] in space or on the ground but thought I saw something organic/alien like floating out of the payload bay.Randy Bresnik and I called the ground to ask what it could be and it was ice that had broken off of the Freon hoses.Melvin was then asked if he thought NASA had just told him that to keep him calm, he replied: “Hmm I don’t think so, but you never know.He added: I was about to say Houston we have a problem but know everyone spins-up when those words are uttered from a space vehicle.”The Space Shuttle Atlantis flew 33 missions during its lifetime and was retired along with the rest of the fleet in 2011.

title: brits lie alcohol intake doctor advice
story: Only two in five Brits tell the truth when quizzed by medics about alcohol intake.The rest fib for a variety of reasons. One in five (20 per cent) never keeps track of how much they are downing.While 14 per cent are scared that the doctor will judge them.The same proportion matches their answer to NHS guidelines.Eleven per cent worry their drinking will be blamed for their medical problem.And ten per cent are embarrassed about the amount they knock back.The poll of 2,008 adults and 191 doctors by Direct Line Life Insurance reveals women under 30 are the most likely to lie.Doctors think a quarter of patients (25 per cent) have a mild drink problem and a fifth (21 per cent) are “highly dependent”.Drinkers risk liver disease, pancreatitis and other conditions.Direct Line spokeswoman Jane Morgan said: “Without all the correct information about your life-style, you may not get the right diagnosis or treatment.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: government british aid rules ignored
story: Development Secretary Penny Mordaunt revealed she has instructed officials not to ask the Treasury for any extra cash for this year’s hurricane season.There was uproar last year when it emerged the UK’s jumbo £13bn aid budget could not be used to help Anguilla and the British Virgin Islands.The British dependencies were left devastated by Hurricane Irma.But the islands were deemed too wealthy for DFID handouts under the international definition of Official Development Assistance.Ms Mordaunt’s bold move means her department will risk spending below the 0.7% foreign aid spending target under the current rigid rules.But the Cabinet minister said: “It is ridiculous that a country which had been flattened by natural disaster shouldn’t qualify for aid as the day before it was doing quite well.“While we lobby to change those rules we will not let them deter what we consider to be the right thing to do.“I believe that is what British taxpayers would wish.”DFID officials admitted there was a “risk” that the bitterly criticised 0.7% target may not be met.But they also claimed enough savings had been made in the department’s administration budget to pay for hurricane relief out of that money pool instead.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jeremy corbyn arsenal takeover mocking
story: Despite refusing to comment on the party turmoil over anti-Semitism or Brexit, the Labour leader issued a statement from his holiday in Somerset to say he backed supporters’ “opposition to this takeover”.And he said it was a real shame fans would lose a voice on the board.The leftie is a lifelong Gunners fan- leading tributes to ex-manager Arsene Wenger when he left in the Spring.But his decision to go public yesterday sparked a backlash on social media sites given the ongoing civil war in the Labour party over its relationship with the Jewish community.One Twitter user said: “Apparently this was more important than addressing the rampant and institutional Antisemitism in Labour including his own shameful actions and words”.In his statement, Mr Corbyn said: “It’s a real shame that this sale will bring to an end the longstanding official role of Arsenal supporters in the running of the club.“I back the Arsenal Supporters Trust’s opposition to this takeover which is sadly an all too familiar story in today’s Premier League.”Mr Corbyn was spotted holidaying in Burnham-on-Sea on Tuesday - where he was seen visiting the Bay View Cafe.The manager told Somerset Live website that the Labour leader was “just going about his day”.Burnham is part of the Wells Constituency, which elected Tory MP James Heappey with more than 50 per cent of the vote last summer.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: david gaut memories grief family
story: Three have been charged with the murder of child killer David Gaut - as it was revealed he was beaten so badly he couldnt be identified at first.David Gaut, 54, had recently been released after he was caged for life in July 1985 for the murder and torture of a 17-month-old boy just 11 miles away.Gwent Police confirmed tonight that three men have been charged with murder.A 47-year-old man, 23-year-old man and 51-year-old man, all from the New Tredegar area are due to appear in Newport Magistrates’ Court tomorrow.Classroom assistant Mary Chabannas, the murdered childs aunt, choked back tears as she recalled the agony it had put her sister Jane Picthall through.She admitted: “This has brought back terrible memories. Jane is my younger sister, I used to look after her little boy myself, I lived in Caerphilly too.“When I had my twins I moved to Birmingham. I had been here just a week when this happened.”A neighbour, who did not want to be named, said: We got to know him quite well since hed moved in.He used to go on about how he had been in prison for 33 years.He told us he had shot a soldier but he told us he had been set up.We were in his flat and saw his middle name was Tracy on the letters he had.We thought that was unusual so I googled him to see if I could find out what he had done.Thats when we saw the details of what he did to the baby boy. We couldnt believe it.Its disgusting. I cant believe we have been living next door to that.Three men - including two near neighbours - have been arrested on suspicion of his murder.Gaut was rehoused in the small ground floor flat by Caerphilly council.Another neighbour said: The flat where it happened is owned by the council, theyre always moving people in and out of them.Who wants to live next door to a child killer or a paedo?The flat and three neighbouring properties were sealed off as cops combed the area for clues.Gaut, then 21, was jailed for life in July 1985 for the murder and torture of a 17-month old boy just 11 miles away in Caerphilly.The beast was babysitting his girlfriends son Chi Ming Shek - known as Marky Pickthall - when he battered, kicked and burned the sole of the childs foot.The babys mum Jane Pickthall, then 23, had been out drinking and left Gaut to look after her two young children.She arrived home in Caerphilly and had sex with Gaut.But the next day she found her sons dead body under a chest of drawers in his bedroom.A murder trial at Cardiff Crown Court heard Gaut tried to make the death look accidental.The baby died of multiple injuries including a broken arm, injured liver and spleen and a fractured skull.A judge described the murder as the worst crime in the land.Sentencing, Mr Justice Caldfield said: The person murdered was a defenceless little baby and on the furys finding you not only murdered that child but also tortured him.Police say Gauts next of kin has been informed and enquiries are continuing.The child killers body was discovered around 3pm on Saturday.A Gwent Police spokesman said: The cause of death has yet to be established and will be determined following a post mortem examination.A spokesman for Caerphilly council said: We can confirm it is a council property and we are helping police with their inquiries.As it is an on-going inquiry it would not be appropriate to comment further.

title: gatwick love darling complaint
story: Bosses said the terms are unprofessional despite being widely used as friendly way of talking to someone.The ban was outlined in a memo by contractor Wilson James, which provides special assistance services to passengers.It stated: “If you do not know the name of the person you are speaking with please refer to them as Sir or Madam.“We are in a customer-facing environment and must remain professional at all times.”But the censure has not gone down well with staff, who accused bosses of over-reacting.One told The Sun: “How small-minded to write a memo like this. The words ‘love’ and ‘darling’ are not derogatory or unprofessional — they’re terms of endearment.You have to wonder about the customer who ­complained too.”Wilson James defended its ban. A spokesman said: “Courteous language is important and we strive to provide regular briefings and reminders to staff of how professional customer engagement should be delivered.”Gatwick officials would not confirm if they support the ban, but said: “We always strive to address each passenger in a professional and courteous manner.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dup ian paisley theresa may
story: Iain Paisley, the North Antrim DUP politician, will face a by-election if the petition – open for six weeks in three locations - is signed by at least 10 per cent of the electorate in the constituency.It came after he was suspended for 30 days for failing to declare two luxury family holidays paid for by the Sri Lankan government which included seven helicopter flights and hospitality for his family worth tens of thousands.He later lobbied then-Prime Minister David Cameron against supporting a UN resolution on human rights abuses in Sri Lanka - again without disclosing the trips.He faces becoming the first MP to lose his seat under the new law introduced by the former coalition government following the Westminster expenses scandal.The MP has a massive 28,000 majority in his constituency after adding 10,000 votes in last year’s general election.But if 7,543 people sign the petition a by-election will be held.Mr Paisley junior, son of DUP founder Ian Paisley, is currently suspended from the DUP pending a party investigation.He has already apologised for what he said was his “unintentional failure” to register the hospitality and has vowed to fight any by-election campaign.The Electoral Office is running the petition process and those signing have to produce a driving licence, UK or Irish passport, electoral identity card or bus or rail pass.The DUP’s 10 pro-Brexit MPs are crucial allies of Prime Minister Theresa May’s minority Government.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: facebook digital wild west trolls sun says
story: These outlaws have long given up any responsibility for the digital Wild West they’ve created.Their platform is polluted from top to bottom, giving trolls free rein and letting every extremist group under the sun publish despicable propaganda.The previous Culture Secretary Matt Hancock was the first to genuinely talk tough to the tech firms and demand that they mend their ways.The new one, Jeremy Wright, must go further and force them to change, because they show precious little appetite to do it themselves.Yes, it’s vital that our privacy is protected. We’d never want authorities to have a free pass to snoop into our lives.But when cops are confident that the missing piece to a case can be found online, it is outrageous that web giants don’t work with them to investigate.They act as if they’re above the law.Let’s see about that.THE new Civil Society Strategy is better than its clunky name suggests.As a general rule, putting power in the hands of local people — rather than leaving it with far-off Whitehall civil servants — is usually a good idea.It is residents who know which roads need fixing, which bins need collecting, and which social care services are struggling.And for all the know-how of local councillors, too many are in safe seats and not solely motivated by serving their voters.Between plans for “citizen juries” and freeing up cash for community organisations, this should be a much-needed boost for local democracy — with the cash to back positive initiatives.The ironic thing is that it all sounds very familiar.It used to be called the Big Society.DAVID Jason reckons Del Boy would have been relaxed about Brexit.Of course he would. title: teenager parasite eye tap water contact lens
story: Skye Wheeler, 19, from Camborne, Cornwall, lives in constant fear that the bug - which is still sleeping in her eye - could cause her to go blind, or even kill her.She was told the microorganism burrowed into her cornea after letting water get between her eye and contact lens when she was 14.It caused her to develop an infection, known as Acanthamoeba keratitis, which has developed into a chronic fatigue syndrome, also known as myalgic encephalomyelitis (ME).The teenager said: The Acanthamoeba Keratitis burrowed into my cornea and ate away to create snail trails around my eye.I was told it is found in tap water. The ultimate mistake was a droplet of water between my eye and my contact lens. It could blind me, or even kill me one day.Despite years of treatment, I still have this parasite in my eye.I am told that it is dormant. It goes into this stage to protect itself, picture it curling into a ball.We will never be able to tell whether it is dead or not or if and when it may reawaken so I have to live with the feeling of never knowing.Skye started to have symptoms of ME, an incurable condition, just a month after coming off the medication doctors prescribed to treat her eye problem.The neurological condition causes extreme exhaustion, pain, brain fog, among a variety of other symptoms.She said: The fatigue is like no other - I actually wish there was another name for it.You cant muster up the energy to put on foot in front of the other.You cant get dressed and ready for the day without a blackness descending over your eyes. You cant carry a conversation let alone even speak.The bottom of the line is that there is no energy there in the first place to channel through your body to all the right places. The only thing you can do is lie and exist.Skye added: My life has been ripped to pieces and then burnt down into nothing but ash and smoke. My life was planned out.I lay in the dark because of light sensitivity alone and waiting for someone to return home and take me to the toilet.My bed is my world. My bed is my support. It has seen me through endless days of torturous pain, fatigue and inner turmoil.Rosie Halsall, 17, from Liverpool, also suffers from ME and was diagnosed just aged nine leaving her wheelchair-bound.At her worst, she was unable to lift her head from her pillow, was spoon-fed and unable to sit for more than 30 minutes without fainting.She said: ME has changed my life. I cant sleep in my bedroom, instead in a downstairs room. Im sensitive to lights and sounds, so regularly wear sound reduction headphones and sunglasses- particularly on bad days.People dont tend to see the bad days, the days when Im crying in pain, when Im too exhausted to wear proper clothes, and the help I need from my parents with washing myself.Both teens have decided to speak out in support of Severe ME Awareness Day and to raise awareness of the condition.A spokesman for the ME Association said: It is an invisible illness. When you see us, we might not always look ill, but when our symptoms flare, the effects are obvious.It can feel like a constant flu, the smallest exertion can floor us, our bodies are painfully sore, restful sleep eludes us, light and noise are intolerable, and brain fog causes confusion.There is no known cure and no effective treatment.

title: naughty good kids school fun day
story: Year 6 students at Arden Primary School in Bredbury, Stockport, had been looking forward a fun day including ice-cream and inflatables with families forking out £10 each to pay for the event.But while the well-behaved students - with the schools Always Badge - were allowed to play on inflatables first, others were made to stay inside and watch.The schools decision has been met with fury from parents.Melissa Jopling, who has an 11-year-old son, told Manchester Evening News: The ones without a badge have already been punished, so why punish them twice?We’re talking about things like not holding a door open for a teacher, or arguing at playtimes. My son had the badge but it was taken away when he was fidgeting in class but that was because they’d taken his fidget spinner off him.The 34-year-old mum - whose son Mika, seven, is still at the school - has launched a petition to get rid of the badges.Other parents have spoken out, with one writing on Facebook: Everyone paid the same amount to do the same fun day. How very wrong is it to punish a child on a fun day when they have already been punished beforehand. Even prisons don’t punish you twice.... imagine getting ten years for a crime and then two days before you get out they give you another ten years.”The schools head teacher Nicola Haddock defended the decision, saying all children had at least two-and-a-half hours on the play equipment.Ms Haddock said: The Year 6 fun day, funded by both parents and our Parent Teacher Association, is a celebration for all of our children. While the children rightly recognised for their continued good behaviour over the school year were given the first place on the inflatables, this was not at the cost of the other children. They had a choice of other activities and time on the inflatables and, with all of our pupils, had equal access to ice-cream.I have investigated the concerns from the parents who have approached the school, as I do with any parental concern, and responded to them personally apologising for any shortcomings they may have felt happened on this day. I will, as always, review the school’s practices in light of parents’ feedback.

title: treasure hunder darrell miklos ufo bermuda triangle
story: Darrell Miklos uses secret maps created by his ex-NASA astronaut pal Gordon Cooper to unearth shipwrecks in the briny deep.But during one of these trawls, intrepid explorer Darrell stumbled across huge mysterious structures that he thinks could change how we view our place in the universe forever.The huge unidentified submerged spaceship is covered in 15 unusual protrusions — which Darrell describes as unlike anything I have ever seen.Darrell, who will show off his other-worldly find on his Discovery Channel show Coopers Treasure, told MailOnline: It was also something that was completely different from anything that Ive seen that was made by nature.The mystery objects were found lying on the seabed near the Bahamas — within the notorious 1.3million km watery grave known as the Bermuda Triangle.It is the scene of countless strange disappearances of planes and ships — attached to which are curious tales that some discredit as myth but others say point to extra-terrestrial or even paranormal happenings.Veteran diver Darrell made his mammoth discovery during a hunt for the wreck of English ships related to the 16th century Brit sea captain Sir Francis Drake.But using maps designed in the 1960s by astronaut Cooper, Darrell detected more than 100 magnetic anomalies at an undisclosed location deep in the Caribbean waters. Describing his approach to his latest find, Darrell said: I was trying to identify shipwreck material based on one of the anomaly readings on Gordons charts when I noticed something that stuck out, that shocked me.He said the object has the appearance of a battleship with a steep wall from which five protruding arms stick out like cannons.Using special breathing apparatus to reach the 300ft-deep spaceship, Darrell said he and his fellow divers noticed that it did not appear to be man-made.And the fact it was covered in thick coral suggested the object — if it landed there from beyond our planet — did so hundreds if not thousands of years ago.Darrell added: Certainly nothing Ive ever seen based on my experience - and I have years of experience at doing this, weve identified multiple different types of shipwreck material - this doesnt match or look anything like that.Looking back at the Cooper charts, Darrell came across a puzzling note left by the former spaceman at the site of the structure — unidentified object.Now, Californian Darrell wants to investigate the mysterious site further — despite the risk he faces of being dubbed an alien conspiracy theorist.The Bermuda Triangle lies in a section of the North Atlantic Ocean which covers a vast area of 440,000 miles of sea.Its one of the busiest shipping lanes in the world, with vessels crossing through to get to ports in America, Europe and the Caribbean.Nicknamed the Devils Triangle it has been blamed for the disappearance of dozens of planes and ships over the past 100 years.When Columbus sailed on his first voyage to the New World, he reported a great flame of fire crashed into the sea one night and that a strange light appeared in the distance a few weeks later.However, reports of unexplained disappearances did not really capture the public’s attention until the 20th century when the USS Cyclops, a 542-foot-long Navy cargo ship with over 300 men on-board, sank somewhere between Barbados and the Chesapeake Bay.One of the most famous mysteries was the disappearance of Flight 19 when five Avenger Torpedo Bombers vanished over the Triangle on December 5, 1945.All 14 men on the flight disappeared without a trace and a Martin Mariner Flying Boat also vanished during the search with 13 men on board.At least 1,000 lives have been lost in the last 100 years. On average, four aircraft and 20 yachts go missing in the area every year.Theories about the Trinagles strange occurences include UFO abductions, a shield to guard the lost city of Atlantis and sinister secret government testing. He wants to remain neutral until he can dig up more evidence on what the structure could be and is hoping to have a third series of his Discovery show commissioned to help tell the story.Hopeful Darrell added: I want to see what it is, because it may be nature-made, just a freak of nature.But given its placement in this particular part of the Caribbean and given what Gordon has told me about visitors from another planet and the things that Ive seen, I think its definitely worthwhile investigating.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: gazza paul gascoigne split art boss sara lovatt
story: Mum-of-two Sara Lovatt said last week that their relationship was early days but added that were having a lot of fun - but the couple have now gone their separate ways.Gazza posted this selfie with a caption confirming that he is now singlePaul Edwards The Sun4Mum-of-two Sara Lovatt has split for Gazza following a brief relationshipOn Twitter Gazza confirmed the split, saying: I’m OK single and find me a girlfriend please.He added: I’ve lost the love of my life my DAD he was my ROLE MODEL X.Mercedes-driving Sara owns the exclusive Antidote Art Gallery in Lutterworth.It was claimed she had been dating the former Tottenham, Rangers and Lazio ace, 51, for a few months and said the star - who has battled drink and drug addictions - is the best he has been for ages.The 49-year-old told the MailOnline: I was never a fan during his football days but I am now.Hes very handsome and really fit and tanned.Hes Paul to me and just a nice, funny guy whos had a tough time.She added: [He] is coping better than his fans are led to believe.Gazzas dad died in February this year but the star insisted at the time that he was in a strong place.And he said he managed to resist returning to drink despite the personal tragedy.The football legend said he last drank before entering rehab on December 2 last year.Just last month, Gazza admitted he still cries over his Italia 90 heartbreak when he famously blubbed on the pitch after receiving a booking which would have ruled him out of the final.

title: tom hardy helps mugger
story: The Hollywood superstar was hailed a hero when he sprinted after the crook, who crashed a stolen moped and fled in London.Screen hardman Hardy, 40, followed the teen thief through gardens and across a building site — before proudly announcing: “I caught the c***.”But Tom has now revealed that he has since reached out to the wayward youth to put him on the right track.Dad-of-two Tom told Esquire: “He must stand accountable for what he’s done.“But he’s got issues, and he’s in a bad way. Do we just give up on a 16-year-old?”The actor, who will star as Marvel anti-hero Venom to be released in October, also humbly played down his superhero antics that were revealed by The Sun.He insisted it wasnt much of a chase when he snared the young yob — adding: When I found him, he was in f***ing rag order.But witnesses said they saw Batman star Hardy vaulting over walls during his pursuit last April.Arun Pullen, 22, said: “It was mental - like he’d switched to superhero mode in an action movie.Two boys on the nicked moped had jumped a red light and smashed into a car.“Tom must have been walking down the road. He went off like a shot in pursuit and looked furious.If the kid had been dumb enough to resist I reckon Tom would have given him a good hiding.”Arun watched as the actor, who lives nearby in Richmond, South West London, hauled the runaway thief into a bus stop — and patted him down for weapons.He said: “The kid looked wrecked and in shock.“Tom Hardy’s clearly not a man you’d mess with. I think he even checked the kid’s ID before cops took over.”Arun said Tom used the C-word to describe the thief.He added: “I asked Tom what happened and he told me he chased him through my back garden and caught him around the block — but the route was like an assault course.”Tom, 39, told one onlooker: “This little s*** nicked something and now he’s got himself a ­broken leg.”The stolen moped carrying two men crashed into a £50,000 Mercedes at a busy road junction.Both thieves were injured. One was caught within moments but the other fled through gardens towards waste ground, where Tom caught up with him and made a citizen’s arrest.Two suspects were arrested on suspicion of theft and taking a vehicle without consent.Arun said: “Tom did the public a great service.”Girlfriend Kalisha added: “I’m a big Tom Hardy fan and there was no mistaking him. He looked as mad as he does on telly.”Tom Hardy’s spokeswoman declined to comment at the time.

title: dad overdosed baby in car photo
story: Michael Krajczynski was found slumped in the driver’s seat as he gurgled incoherently after downing two pills in Woonsocket, Rhode Island on Friday afternoon.Emergency responders were forced to administer four doses of Narcan, which is used to treat opiate overdoses, before taking the 33-year-old to hospital.After regaining his senses, the dad-of-five told cops he had taken two white pills he believed to be OxyContin, an opioid-class painkiller, as he was suffering shoulder pain.He admitted that the pills were not prescribed by the doctor.Krajczynski told officers that he “began to feel strange” around ten minutes after taking them, and was forced to pull his car over as the effects began to take hold.He confessed to police that he had “made a bad decision” and was charged with cruelty or neglect of a child.The state Department of Children, Youth and Families was notified and the child was reunited with his mother.Speaking to NBC10, the family described Krajczynski as a “good father to five children” and confirmed that he did not have a drug habit.His wife also confirmed that Krajczynski had been on prescribed pain medication following surgery, and after his own stash ran out, he had taken some from a friend.The young dad was released pending a court appearance on August 30.Officers chose to take a photograph of the scene when they arrived to highlight how often they come across this scenario.It is not the first time that officers have chosen to name and shame parents who have overdosed with their children metres away from them.Last September, police in Ohio released harrowing images of a couple passed out in their car with a child in the back in an effort to highlight the devastating effects of heroin addiction.The pictures were posted to the police department’s Facebook page after the pair were pulled over for driving erratically.They wrote: We feel it necessary to show the other side of this horrible drug.We feel we need to be a voice for the children caught up in this horrible mess.This child cant speak for himself but we are hopeful his story can convince another user to think twice about injecting this poison while having a child in their custody.Just weeks later, Florida cops wearing bodycams found two mums overdosing on heroin in a car while their babies were the back seat.Kristen Leigh O’Connor, 27, of Coral Springs and June Ann Schweinhart, 28, of Lake Worth, were found slumped unconscious in a heroin stupor, with their newborns strapped in the back of the vehicle.Both were charged with child neglect and the children were taken into social services.US deaths from drug overdoses rose 21 per cent in 2016, and have significantly contributed to the decline in life expectancy in America.For the first time, the powerful painkiller Fentanyl and its close opioid cousins were a bigger factor in the deaths than any other legal or illegal drug, surpassing prescription pain pills and heroin.Two-thirds of the 42,000  drug deaths in 2016 involved opioids, a category that includes heroin, methadone, prescription pain pills like OxyContin, and Fentanyl.The highest drug death rates were recorded in ages 25 to 54.

title: staithes cliffs north yorkshire beach
story: Emergency services rushed to the scene but were unable to save the tragic schoolgirl.Staithes is a seaside destination in North Yorkshire, ten miles north of Whitby.The picturesque fishing village lies in the North York Moors National Park.CBBC series Old Jacks Boat is set and filmed there.A nine-year-old girl died after suffering serious head head injuries when rocks fell from a cliff on Seaton Garth beach in Staithes.Eyewitnesses told the BBC the girl was on holiday with her family and the incident happened where there were warning signs about the cliff.Staithes coastguards confirmed a section of the cliff fell on the afternoon of August 8, 2018.In a statement it said: Numerous calls were made to the emergency services after a section of the cliff fell.Thank you to all the Emergency Services, Coastguard Teams and personnel for their very best efforts.It is not yet known whether the cliffs have collapsed or people have been injured in this area before.Some of the cliffs in Seaton Garth carry signs saying: Beware dangerous cliffs.Locals were left reeling by the incident, with one saying they had never seen anything like it.An inquest will take place in due course.

title: us sanctions on russia bring political gain before midterms
story: Despite Donald Trump's history of charting a course often at odds with his own departments and agencies, especially on Russia, this time it is pretty safe to assume the president will toe the line.In part that is because there is political gain to be had here.The midterms are coming.A strong, decisive president, wielding power against adversarial nations like Iran and Russia, will play well with the Republican base.It is also useful that the new sanctions come at a time when Mr Trump is facing ongoing criticism that he is too close to Moscow, and as the constant drum beat of special counsel Robert Mueller's collusion investigation continues.Separately, there is also a broader issue relating to the necessity of dealing with existential threats.

title: winning contests gives men testosterone boost study suggests
story: The study's lead author, Dr Danny Longman, explained that the body attempts to take advantage of the apparent social improvement by inducing chemical and thus behavioural changes that promote a "short-term" approach to reproductive success.Dr Longman explained: "Much of evolution consists of trade-offs in energy investment."One reproductive approach is short-term, investing time and energy in attracting and pursuing many mates, and fighting off competition. Another approach is long-term, investing energy in raising offspring with a single mate."We found that a perceived shift in social status can cause male physiology to adapt by preparing to shift mating strategies to optimise reproductive success."Dr Longman added: "The endocrine system that controls hormones is responsive to situational changes. Previous research has shown that testosterone is lower when men are in a committed relationship, or have children, to promote long-term mating strategies."Our results show that both testosterone and its corresponding psychological effects can fluctuate quickly and opportunistically, shifting towards short-term mating in response to a perceived change in status that may increase mating value."Speaking to Sky News, Dr Longman said that the results tapped into "one of the most defining abilities in human evolution - the ability to adapt into changing environmental conditions"."Many species have to rely on genetic changes within new environments, but we can change our physiology quickly without this need to make a genetic change."The evolution of the human brain and its ability to release hormones that change out physiology quickly has been crucial to human success, explained the anthropologist."Very generally, the mind and the body are completely intertwined. Our mind senses changes in the environment and our body enacts physiological changes as a result of that."Although physical strength is the dominant indicator of male social status in many modern societies, Dr Longman said he was curious to see if similar results arose from intellectual challenges in the office-based culture many men now inhabit.

title: 15 senior tories who called
story: News15 top Tories berating Boris Johnson's burqa outburst - and what they saidThe former Foreign Secretary faces fury from his own party colleagues - here's how they've criticised himShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAndrew GregoryPolitical Editor21:00, 8 AUG 2018Updated07:29, 9 AUG 2018NewsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBoris Johnson is under mounting pressure to apologise for a newspaper column in which he compared women wearing face veils to 'bank robbers' and 'letterboxes'. At least 15 senior Tory figures have demanded he apologise. But the former Foreign Secretary has defied Theresa May by refusing to say sorry for his remarks. In the piece, Mr Johnson argued against Denmark banning the burka. But he made several comparisons between the covering worn by some women, saying it made them look like “bank robbers” or “letter boxes”. Mr Johnson also revealed he would “feel entitled” to ask a woman wearing the burka to remove it if she came to his constituency office. Here's how top Tories have reacted to the comments.  Theresa May  Prime Minister   I do think that we all have to be very careful about the language and terms we use. And some of the terms Boris used describing people's appearance obviously have offended. So I agree with Brandon Lewis. What's important is do we believe people should have the right to practise their religion and, in the case of women and the burka and niqab, to choose how they dress. I believe women should be able to choose how they dress. Brandon Lewis  Conservative Party chair   “I do think Boris should apologise. I do agree with Boris we should be able to have a debate but we’ve got to be sure to use the right language.” Ruth Davidson  Conservative Party Scotland leader   I think it's also not been shown through history that when men make sweeping statements about what women should or shouldn't wear that it goes well for them. I think that this wasn't an off-the-cuff slip, he wrote a column, he knew exactly what he was doing and I think it crossed from being provocative and starting a debate and actually it became rude and gratuitous. I think he should apologise for them. It doesn't bode well, and we've seen it in the arguments and the debate over anti-Semitism in Labour, of how we've got to a point in 2018 where we're supposed to be so much better at accepting and discussing and being open about different faiths, religions, backgrounds, social classes, all of these things, and actually we've become slightly even more siloed and treating them differently. If you use the analogy of Christianity, would you ever write in the  that you should have a debate about banning Christians from wearing crucifixes?  It's the same argument but it's in a different faith so why are the parameters different for one faith and not the other? That's where I think you start getting these questions of what constitutes anti-Semitism, what constitutes Islamophobia, and if you have that comparator in your mind then that perhaps is a better guidance for not what you should or shouldn't say, but how you frame the debate. I agree with the point of his piece which was you shouldn't ban the burka, the niqab, the hijab - I don't think we should ban it - but what he said was a gratuitously offensive way of saying it. Jeremy Wright  Culture Secretary   When you are discussing a subject such as this, then I think describing it as people looking like letter boxes isn't helpful. I think we should all choose our language with care. That's the sort of language I think we should try and avoid using. Alistair Burt  Foreign Office Minister   “I would never have made such a comment. I think there’s a degree of offence in that, absolutely right.” Tobias Ellwood  Armed Forces Minister   Boris has many talents, but his attack on Muslim women for their appearance is not the way to defend freedom of religion. Now more than ever, we must communicate the integrity &amp inclusiveness of the Conservative Party. Penny Mordaunt  Equalities Minister   Brandon Lewis has done the right thing. Remember only two things are the case: either a woman wants to wear the niqab, or she does not. If you want to support women who do not want to wear the niqab I recommend giving Masih Alinejad and others a follow. Dominic Grieve  former Attorney General   If he were to become leader of the party, I for one wouldn't be in it. I don't regard him as a fit and proper person to lead a political party and certainly not the Conservative Party. He is somebody who seems to me to pursue an agenda that is entirely self-referential, doesn't take account of colleagues. He wasn't able to observe Cabinet responsibility when he was in government. Lord Sheikh  Conservative Muslim Forum president   Take the whip from him. Why not? He's not a super human being, he's a member of the party. The party chairman, the Prime Minister has the right to take the whip. That's the thing I'd like to see. Baroness Sayeeda Warsi  former Conservative Party chair   As a feminist, what really disgusts me in this whole episode is that Muslim women are simply political fodder, their lives a convenient battleground on which to stake out a leadership bid. Boris Johnson’s contempt for Muslim women is part of a dangerous pattern. “Well, this approach is not just offensive, it’s dangerous. Johnson’s words have once again validated the view of those that ‘other’ Muslims. They send out a message that Muslim women are fair game. “What starts as useful targets for ‘colourful political language’ and the odd bit of toxic campaigning ends up in attacks on our streets. “Muslim women should not be a useful political battleground for Old Etonians. “It is crass and it must stop, and it must be condemned by the leadership right from the Prime Minister down.” Lord Eric Pickles  former Conservative Party chair   There are tensions now that exist within the community, a degree of hatred out there that I've not witnessed for a good few years. If this was a councillor from Scunthorpe or Middlesbrough or somewhere I'm not entirely sure he would have been given the amount of slack and, in truth, he wouldn't have been given the amount of attention, that Boris has got. Paul Masterton  Conservative MP   “No one is shutting down debate. “They are pointing out it’s possible to argue for empowerment and religious freedom of women and girls, come to the view you are against a ban on the burqa in public places (as he did), all without mocking women who do wear one for their appearance. Heidi Allen  Conservative MP   “About as suitable to be Prime Minister as he was Foreign Secretary.” Anna Soubry  Conservative MP   Boris Johnson's comments on what some Muslim women choose to wear are offensive - in my honest opinion they fuel Islamaphobia. Jonathan Djanogly  Conservative MP

title: first time buyers left high
story: NewsFirst-time buyers left high and dry as number of cheaper homes plunges under the ToriesEXCLUSIVE: Just 7,245 new affordable homes to buy were funded by the government last year - down from 20,298 in 2009/10Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter19:00, 8 AUG 2018Updated09:41, 9 AUG 2018NewsTheresa May declared it was her “personal mission to restore the dream of home-ownership” (Image: Getty)Get politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFirst-time buyers have been left high and dry after the number of cheaper homes plunged under the Tories. Just 7,245 new affordable homes to buy were funded by the government last year - down from 20,298 in 2009/10. Official figures show the number of those homes completed fell for four years in a row after the Tories took power, and hit a low point of 4,280 in 2015/16. It comes despite Theresa May declaring in January that it was her “personal mission to restore the dream of home-ownership”. Labour claimed 77,000 fewer affordable homes to buy had been built than if construction had continued at the 2009/10 rate.  Shadow Housing Secretary John Healey said: “Theresa May and the Conservatives have talked big but delivered little for those locked out of home-ownership. “Ministers have slashed direct help for first-time buyers on middle incomes by cutting funding for low-cost homes such as shared ownership.” The figures are for affordable homes to buy that were funded by either Homes England or the Greater London Authority. They mainly cover “shared ownership” homes, where buyers take out a mortgage on part of their property and pay rent on the rest. Some 20,298 were completed in 2009/10, the earliest year for which figures were available - followed by 16,726 in 2010/11, 15,144 in 2011/12, 14,753 in 2012/13, 8,710 in 2013/14, 12,257 in 2014/15, 4,280 in 2015/16, 5,864 in 2016/17 and 7,245 in 2017/18. It comes after a Chartered Institute of Housing report in May found government investment in affordable housing had been slashed from &pound4.2bn in 2009/10 to &pound483m in 2016/17.

title: gareth thomas dont sell wembley
story: NewsopinionGareth Thomas: Don't sell Wembley Stadium - tax the TV rights billions to fund grassroots football insteadInstead of flogging Wembley to fund grassroots sport, we need a 10% levy on TV rights, writes north London MP Gareth ThomasShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByGareth Thomas MP15:11, 8 AUG 2018NewsopinionThere must be a better way to fund grassroots sport, writes Gareth Thomas MP (Image: Alex Morton)Get politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email We shouldn't be selling off Wembley Stadium - the iconic home to England’s football team and a huge money-spinner.  The Football Association says it would plough a windfall into grassroots sport for 20 years. But there are other, better ways to do this. As the Premier League kicks off this weekend, it continues to receive at least &pound3billion from domestic and overseas TV rights. It’s not hard to see how England’s richest clubs have so much money to share around between themselves. So the FA should be demanding the government introduce a levy of 10% on the TV income Premier League clubs receive.  This would help nurture the next generation of Harry Kanes, Jordan Pickfords, and Kieron Trippiers. Grassroots football in England is, unfortunately, not as healthy as the Premier League's prize pot. Only one in three grass pitches are of adequate quality to play football in England, and last season one in six matches were cancelled due to poor facilities. Meanwhile taxpayers paid out more than &pound160million to build Wembley. So any decision to sell off this nationally important venue should not be taken before other alternatives have been exhausted. The Premier League currently puts just &pound100million into grassroots football- a pitiful contribution given how wealthy its clubs are.

title: its ridiculous anyone would go
story: NewsopinionIt's ridiculous anyone would go around talking like Boris Johnson - which is exactly why he does itBoris Johnson is the MP for Boris Johnson, and that's the only principle he's gotShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist12:23, 8 AUG 2018Updated12:31, 8 AUG 2018NewsopinionGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe scene is a townhouse in north London. The honourable Member of Parliament for Boris Johnson is considering his next move. The Opposition is making headlines by chewing its own entrails over whether or not it likes Jews. The country is stockpiling food and medicines, while grass fires rage, cows go hungry and farmers talk of disaster. To make matters worse, he is being made to look incompetent by Jeremy Hunt, of all people, and Jacob Rees-Mogg is being spoken of as the next Prime Minister because he sounds clever. Grumble grumble and bugger me, Marina, but old Boris is benched! No-one is talking about Brilliant BJ. Damned impolite when I resigned on a matter of principle, having not displayed one iota of principle for the entirety of the 54 years I have given humanity the benefit of my existence. Well, I had a call on the telephoney-what-not the other day from Steve Bannon, you know, the man who looks like a suppurating tumour and got Donald Trump elected. He said I can take control of the news by saying mad and bonkers stuff, more mad and bonkers than normal anyway, not British bonkers but Trumpian bonkers. The fake news will faithfully report it all and the racists will love me, and all the racists-but-pretending-they-aren't will say they're supporting my economic policies.  So I asked the editor of the Waily Torygraph if they'd like me to write something that would get lots of attention, and they said they could do with something like that, and here it is, Marina old girl! If this doesn't get me on top of the news agenda for a solid week then nothing will!   Let me read it to you. I spent five whole minutes on it, it's really good. Listen.  Ahem. If you tell me that we do not have enough state control over what women wear, then I will man the barricades with you, comrades! Let us rip from Muslim women their headscarves, bare the bodies masked by burqas, remark upon the beauty or otherwise of faces covered by niqabs!  It is the sovereign duty of every Englishman, fwar fwar fwar, to see whatever bit of a woman they fancy. Especially if they've got dusky skin. Why, I regularly tell my wife to walk around in a balaclava purely so I can exercise my human right, guaranteed at the signing of Magna Carta, to jump out from behind a tree and rip it off again. And that's why we need to make the Queen walk around naked. Our monarch must set an example that British integration means women being told what to wear, and accepting that most days she looks like a knitted German egg cosy.  I am not in any way being racist. Did I say racist? I didn't mean to. It's what people will call me, of course, racist, but don't let us repeat the word racist in case it causes extra headlines about racism. So many items of female clothing are oppressive, and a truly liberal nation such as ours should not allow women of any race to totter along in high heels, thoughtlessly mimicking the billions of victims of Chinese foot-binding, nor the menace of winter tights that go all bobbly after a single wash and make them look like shabby French mime artists, coming over here and stealing the jobs of Ango-Saxon street artistes.  But let us not stop there, my brethren. Let us also call out the controlling nature of corduroy, the Nazi obsession with nylon, the perverted prevalance of polyester and wrongness of rayon. Nature made totty to titivate us, not to be hidden away! If this makes me a militant feminist then I am happy to confess I am one of the sisterhood.  And don't get me started on people who cover up their God-given bodies for religious reasons. The priesthood attracts paedophiles precisely because their vestments give them the perfect excuse to hide their true natures. And nuns! They're basically just angry penguins, aren't they? Penguins who flatten the wages of British Protestants.   And hair! Women shouldn't be allowed it, for it covers their skulls! Pluck out their eyelashes, epilate their eyebrows, render them clean of fuzz!  Say so long to saris. Wave bye-bye to baggy sweat pants, winter jumpers, 1920s vintage clothing, duffel coats and pyjamas. No woman needs them, and I say so in a spirit of weird and bullying adoration of the female form because otherwise we'll be overrun by half-drowned picaninnies.  In a spirit of gender equality I will also point out that not all men in crash helmets are acid-wielding murderers on a rampage, and of course we should not ban them as that would be an example of nanny state control. But if I make you worry about them, you'll be ripping helmets off little kids on trikes by the end of the week, won't you? Vote for Boris.  The hard truth everyone in this politically-correct world is too frightened to say is that it's simply ridiculous for people to choose to go around looking like letter boxes. Dogs urinating on them! Post being shoved into their cakeholes! Being turned to gold with the curse of King Midas if there's an Olympian nearby! The working classes being oppressed yet again by the elite, of whom I am most definitely one and therefore was born to be PM.    If a woman spoke to me I should feel fully entitled to ask her to divest herself of all clothes first so I could talk to her tits properly. After all, this is how humans have evolved to work. There's no mention of leather jackets in scripture, you know. Off with that woman's head.  It applies also to children with cancer, the malingering little brats, in those hospital gowns they just hide sweets in. Little old ladies in tweed, scarecrows in straw hats, roadworkers lurking behind shapeless hi-vis jackets while treacherously talking this country down. This doesn't mean we should ban clothes or the right of any man or woman to wear what they please when going about their own business. It just means no-one's been talking about Boris since I resigned, apart from the 1,704 mentions I've had since then in British newspapers, and that's not good enough.  So if I say Muslim women look like bank robbers, act all offended when you say I've offended them, and grab lots of headlines while people fail to notice that my 'hard truth' is the same as saying anyone in a mini-skirt is a prostitute , then I'll get away with encouraging millions of people to attack women in the street just to prove they're victims of someone else.  Whaddya think, Marina? Churchillian in its sweep, I think future historians will agree, and so illogical as to take up most of the country's mental bandwidth as they try to understand it and fail to spot that I have become an integral, entertaining and, most worryingly of all, taken-seriously part of their lives. Jolly clever of me, really, ain't it? They'll never notice, and the Tory faithful will lap it up. Next week, I will tell them we need to build a wall on our northern border and make the Scots pay for it, that the NHS must be dismantled for the good of our health and the RAF must shoot down any planes with Muslims on board. We'll call it Boris' Battle of Britain. Rah!

title: labour mp arctic mission investigate
story: NewsLabour MP on Arctic mission to investigate plastic pollution - 55 years after her father's polar expeditionEXCLUSIVE: Anna McMorrin will visit the Arctic Circle almost six decades after her dad Ian was on the British Antarctic SurveyShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor21:00, 8 AUG 2018Updated09:42, 9 AUG 2018NewsAnna McMorrin with her father IanGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA campaigning MP is spending part of Parliament’s summer recess visiting the Arctic in an emotional journey mirroring an expedition taken by her dad almost six decades ago. Labour backbencher Anna McMorrin sets out for the frozen North later this month - 55 years after her father Ian was on the British Antarctic Survey. He died in October aged 79 - but Anna is keeping his memory alive with her fact-finding mission at the top of the world. “My trip pales into insignificance compared to his, but it will be really interesting to get even the tiniest little glimpse of the kind of environment that my father was in nearly 60 years ago,” she said.  “I was always really proud of him for having done it, because it’s not everyone’s dad who has been to the Antarctic. “Growing up, I remember his many stories of life in that vast, beautiful, untouched landscape and how the natural world shaped him. “His passion for the environment and his determination to change things has stayed with me.” Cardiff North MP Anna, 46, and colleagues from the Commons Environmental Audit Committee will investigate how micro-plastic contamination is harming marine life. They will see first-hand the affects of climate change and plastic pollution on the Arctic Circle. Her father’s pioneering work in the early 1960s included looking at the difference in weather patterns and ice. His contribution to research was immortalised in the naming of the McMorrin Glacier.  Ian was one of 12 researchers despatched to the Antarctic in 1961 - and his tales of the mission involving sleds, huskies and whales kept Anna and her sister gripped at bedtime. The proud MP said: “One of the stories he used to tell me and my sister was when he was going out in a little boat to catch fish, which they had to do to survive. “If you fell in the water you literally had seconds to live. “He turned around and suddenly this huge eye had risen next to the boat, and it was a huge whale.  “He just sat there absolutely still because he knew that with one flick of the tail, if they ended up in the water they would be dead. “This whale came over, looked at them and submerged itself and swam way. Life was hard for the duration of the trip. “One boat came to them with supplies during the whole time there were there, so it really was completely cut off, she said. “They had letters sent to them but obviously they got them all at once so they would store them up.” Ian’s passion for exploration and science rubbed off on his daughter, fuelling her own quest years later.

title: teenage ballerina who lost leg
story: NewsTeenage ballerina who lost leg at age two fulfills her dream to dance on her toesPollyanna Hope has pursued her dreams of being a top ballet dancer despite only having one leg and has now had new leg with allows her to point toes for first timeShare&nbspBySara Wallis10:13, 9 AUG 2018NewsPollyanna shows off her dancing skills (Image: TIM ANDERSON)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDetermined to fulfil her dream of becoming a ballerina despite a disability, Pollyanna Hope was forced to take matters into her own hands and began furiously fashioning her own ballet pointe shoe. Taking a plastic cup and some tape, she attached it to her prosthetic leg and matter-of-factly began dancing around the room. The 13-year-old lost her leg in a horrific bus crash when she was just two years old – a tragedy that seriously injured her mother Sarah and killed her grandmother Elizabeth - but has always wanted to be able to stand on tip-toes like other dancers. Unfortunately there has been no prosthetic to allow her to do this. But in emotional scenes in a TV doc tonight, viewers will see an inventor help Pollyanna, so that she no longer has to try to make her own.  Her mum Sarah, 46, explains: “Pollyanna attaches a plastic cup to her leg with gaffer tape. Once she made another pointe leg out of a Pringles tube. She just decided that despite what anyone said, she could do it. She was always dancing around the kitchen on her own.” Pollyanna has always refused to let her disability hold her back despite 21 operations and more than 20 prosthetics over the last decade, but the ballet world is unforgiving and she remembers one particularly tough moment. “In my ballet exam I got marks off because I didn't point my foot,” says Pollyanna. “It's quite difficult to point your foot when you don't have a foot.” Sarah, who won a Daily Mirror Pride of Britain award for her campaigning and charity work around prosthetics and child amputees, adds: “Pollyanna was about seven. It was quite hard when the results came out. “Pollyanna has quite good musicality and is naturally quite elegant, but she was marked down for footwork. She scraped a pass and all her other little friends got distinction. We didn't want her to grow up thinking she couldn't do anything, so we decided we didn't want her to do exams. “She gave up ballet for a while and became a national champion in horse riding for the Riding for the Disabled Association. But when she was 10 she wanted to do ballet again.”  Pollyanna, who lives in Harpenden with mum Sarah, dad Christopher, sister Sapphire, 16, and brother Barnaby, 18, was even asked to audition for the Royal Ballet when she was 11. “There was a lot of build up which was all quite positive and exciting, then we got a two-line rejection email,” recalls Sarah. “She didn't make a song and dance about it, she just moved on. “The Royal Ballet may have said no, but she thought 'Well I can actually.' She filmed herself dancing in our kitchen and put it on YouTube. It got thousands of hits.” After that, dad Christopher, 46, put the video out on social media with the message: “My daughter wants to do ballet, who can help?” The family was bombarded with messages from across the globe offering solutions. That's when they were contacted by the team from the BBC2 documentary, Inventing The Impossible: Big Life Fix, which sees inventors and engineers come up with solutions for those who face day-to-day difficulties. In the doc, inventor Yusuf Mohammed is tasked with creating a new prosthetic leg for Pollyanna. Viewers will see Pollyanna pirouetting across the room on her blade, before working with Yusuf to come up with something that allows her to move onto her toes. “The leg is brilliant,” says Sarah. “She has beaten off competition from around 200 able-bodied children to win a place on a contemporary dance course in London and will take the leg and see how she gets on. She got the place because of her drive, her potential and her talent.

title: burglar caught after left dna
story: NewsBurglar caught after he left his DNA on a block of cheeseLabourer Jamie Simmonds left behind a trail of cheese crumbs as he made off with the Red LeicesterShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAdam Aspinall18:16, 8 AUG 2018Updated18:18, 8 AUG 2018NewsJamie Simmonds (Image: WALES NEWS SERVICE)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A greedy burglar was snared when his DNA was discovered on a stolen block of cheese.  Jamie Simmonds, 29, targeted his ex-girlfriend’s mum’s house in a “revenge attack”, a court heard. But the labourer left behind a trail of cheese crumbs as he made off with the Red Leicester. Forensics analysed them and found Simmonds’s DNA on the cheese. The raid was directed at his ex Molly Patterson, Cardiff crown court heard.
